'''Arbee Stidham''' (February 9, 1917<ref name="AMG"/> – April 26, 1988) was an American [[blues]] singer and [[multi-instrumentalist]], most successful in the late 1940s and 1950s.

He was born in [[De Valls Bluff, Arkansas]], [[United States]], to a musical family - his father, Luddie Stidham played with [[Jimmie Lunceford]] and his uncle with the [[Memphis Jug Band]]. Arbie Stidham learned to play harmonica, clarinet and saxophone as a child.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p20760/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Ron Wynn |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=October 13, 2011}}</ref>  Before his teens he had formed his own band, the Southern Syncopators, which backed [[Bessie Smith]] on tour in 1930-31, and played on radio and in clubs in Arkansas and [[Memphis, Tennessee]].  

In the mid-1940s he moved to Chicago and met [[Lester Melrose]], who signed him to [[RCA Victor]] in 1947.<ref name="AMG"/> His biggest hit, "[[My Heart Belongs to You]]", was recorded at his first session, and reached # 1 on the [[United States|US]] ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|R&B]] [[record chart|chart]] in June 1948.<ref>{{cite book |title= Top R&B/Hip-Hop Singles: 1942-2004|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=2004 |publisher=Record Research |page=552}}</ref>  He spent the rest of his career trying to emulate its success, recording for [[Checker Records|Checker]], [[States Records|States]], and other [[independent record label]]s as a [[jazz]]-influenced blues vocalist.  After a car accident made it impossible to play the [[saxophone]], he took up the guitar in the 1950s under the tutelage of [[Big Bill Broonzy]], and played it on his early 1960s recordings for [[Folkways Records|Folkways]].

Stidham continued to record occasionally up to the early 1970s, and also made many [[music festival]] and club appearances nationwide and internationally.  He lectured on the blues at [[Cleveland State University]] in the 1970s, and appeared in the film ''The Bluesman'' in 1973.<ref name="AMG"/>

He died April 26, 1988 in [[Cook County, Illinois]], aged 71.<ref>[http://www.secondhandsongs.com/artist/34780 Secondhandsongs.com]</ref>
